across.text: Rug with a motif originally in tent-like dwelling
across.explanation: WIGWAM(i.e. “tent-like dwelling”). Solution is WIG (i.e. “rug”) followed by W (a recognised abbreviation of “with”) then A and M (i.e. “motif originally”, i.e. the first letter of “motif”).

across.text: “Green Mountain Record Company” spoken of in Asian city
across.explanation: RAWALPINDI(i.e. “Asian city”). Solution is RAW (i.e. “green” or inexperienced) followed by ALP (i.e. “mountain”) and a homophone (indicated by “spoken of”) of INDIE (i.e. “record company”), like so: RAW-ALP-INDI.

across.text: Chinese dog drinking first of oolong tea
across.explanation: PEKOE(i.e. “tea”). Solution is PEKE (i.e. “Chinese dog”, short for Pekinese) wrapped around or “drinking” O (i.e. “first [letter] of oolong”), like so: PEK(O)E. One I remembered from an earlier puzzle, if I’m honest.

across.text: Hit back, seeing extremely rude woman in gallery
across.explanation: RETALIATE(i.e. “hit back”). Solution is RE (i.e. “extremely rude”, i.e. the first and last letters of “rude”) followed by ALI (i.e. “woman’s” name) once placed “in” TATE (i.e. “gallery”), like so: RE-T(ALI)ATE.

across.text: Inaccuracy of English bishop, one with an old American cape
across.explanation: ERRONEOUSNESS(i.e. “inaccuracy”). Solution is E (a recognised abbreviation of “English”) followed by RR (i.e. “bishop”, specifically a Right Reverend), then ONE, then O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”), then US (i.e. “American”) and NESS (i.e. “cape”, as in the geographic feature), like so: E-RR-ONE-O-US-NESS.

across.text: A container that briefly reveals a prickly structure
across.explanation: ACANTHA(i.e. “prickly structure”, i.e. a thorn or spine). Solution is A followed by CAN (i.e. “container”) and THAT once the last letter has been removed (indicated by “briefly”), like so: A-CAN-THA.

across.text: Functions involving army once in Surrey town
across.explanation: STAINES(i.e. “Surrey town”). Solution is SINES (i.e. mathematical “functions”) wrapped around or “involving” TA (i.e. “army once”, specifically the Territorial Army), like so: S(TA)INES.

across.text: What one should not do to welcome public support!
across.explanation: OUTSTAY(i.e. “what one should not do to welcome”). Solution is OUT (i.e. “public”) followed by STAY (i.e. “support”, e.g. a mainstay).

across.text: He had to garden to get working for the elite
across.explanation: THE GREAT AND THE GOOD(i.e. “the elite”, often ironically). “Working” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of HE HAD TO GARDEN TO GET.

across.text: The last word in glam entertainment
across.explanation: AMEN(i.e. “the last word”). “In” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, like so: GL(AM EN)TERTAINMENT.

across.text: Fast mover runs to left of maple tree
across.explanation: RACER(i.e. “fast mover”). Solution is R (a recognised abbreviation of “runs”) followed by ACER (i.e. “maple tree”).

across.text: A girl has ways to replace last of these old quibblers
across.explanation: SOPHISTS(i.e. “old quibblers”). Solution is SOPHIE (i.e. “a girl’s” name) with the E (i.e. “last [letter] of these”) “replaced” by STS (i.e. “ways”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “street” made plural), like so: SOPHI(E)=>SOPHI(STS). Chalk one to my Bradford’s here as I’d gotten the arse with the puzzle by this point.

across.text: Greeting woman reportedly in charge of sanitation
across.explanation: HYGIENIC(i.e. “of sanitation”). Solution comprises homophones (indicated by “reportedly”) of HI (i.e. “greeting”) and JEAN (i.e. “woman’s” name), plus IC (a recognised abbreviation of “in charge”), like so: HY-GIEN-IC.

across.text: Mousy girl with swept-back hair the writer’s pursuing?
across.explanation: UNASSERTIVE(i.e. “mousy”). Solution is UNA (i.e. “girl”) followed by TRESS (i.e. “hair”) reversed (indicated by “swept-back”), then I’VE (i.e. “the writer’s” – in this case a contraction of “the writer has” rather than “the writer is” – taken from the point of view of the setter), like so: UNA-SSERT-I’VE.

across.text: Slogan originally coined at church wears thin, we’re told
across.explanation: CATCHPHRASE(i.e. “slogan”). Solution is C (i.e. “originally coined”, i.e. the first letter of “coined”) followed by AT, then CH (a recognised abbreviation of “church”) and a homophone (indicated by “we’re told”) of FRAYS (i.e. “wears thin”), like so: C-AT-CH-PHRASE.

across.text: Killer serving sentence – keeping busy? Not at first
across.explanation: INSECTICIDE(i.e. “killer”). Solution is INSIDE (i.e. “serving sentence”) wrapped around or “keeping” HECTIC (i.e. “busy”) once its initial letter has been removed (indicated by “not at first”), like so: INS(ECTIC)IDE.

across.text: Assertive supporter’s revolutionary songs heard by Queen
across.explanation: CHEERLEADER(i.e. “assertive supporter”). Solution is CHE Guevara (i.e. “revolutionary”) and a homophone (indicated by “heard”) of LIEDER (i.e. “songs”) once this latter has been placed after or “by” ER (i.e. “Queen”, specifically Elizabeth Regina), like so: CHE-(ER)-LEADER.

across.text: Old dignitary conceals slip, fifth of harvest being past its best
across.explanation: OVERRIPE(i.e. “being past its best”). Solution is O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”) and VIP (i.e. “dignitary” or Very Important Person) once wrapped around or “concealing” ERR (i.e. “slip”). This is all then followed by E (i.e. “fifth [letter] of harvest”), like so: O-V(ERR)IP-E.

across.text: Small number arresting posh fool, one on the run
across.explanation: FUGITIVE(i.e. “one on the run”). Solution is FIVE (i.e. “small number”) wrapped around or “arresting” U (i.e. “posh” – U is sometimes used to denote the upper classes, what, what, what) and GIT (i.e. “fool”), like so: F(U-GIT)IVE.

across.text: Traps detective swigging the hard stuff
across.explanation: DRUMS(i.e. “traps” – a jazz term denoting drums or other percussive instruments(pats Chambers)). Solution is DS (i.e. “detective”, specifically a Detective Sergeant) wrapped around or “swigging” RUM (i.e. “the hard stuff”), like so: D(RUM)S.

across.text: Winged creature identified by old woman without hesitation
across.explanation: MOTH(i.e. “winged creature”). Solution is MOTHER (i.e. one’s “old woman”) with the ER removed (indicated by “without hesitation”).

across.text: Avoid stirring up trouble – don’t disturb dozy setters!
across.explanation: LET SLEEPING DOGS LIE. Solution satisfies “avoid stirring up trouble” and “don’t disturb dozy setters”.

across.text: Roughly shows impatience on road, maybe, finding collusion
across.explanation: CAHOOTS(i.e. “collusion”). Solution is CA (i.e. “roughly”, i.e. a recognised abbreviation of “circa”) followed by HOOTS (i.e. “shows impatience on road” – pah! Maybe back in the 1950s, gramps. Modern motoring etiquette compels drivers to aggressively tailgate people, then force them to the roadside and bludgeon them with whatever comes to hand).

across.text: Opposed to a way profit is secured
across.explanation: AGAINST(i.e. “opposed to”). Solution is A and ST (i.e. “way”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “street”) between which is “secured” GAIN (i.e. “profit”), like so: A-(GAIN)-ST.

across.text: As loose shoes, perhaps, not spiked
across.explanation: UNLACED. Solution satisfies “as loose shoes” and a drink that is “not spiked”.

across.text: School in a rut, a terrible state
across.explanation: SOUTH CAROLINA(i.e. “[US] state”). “Terrible” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of SCHOOL IN A RUT A.

across.text: Grand heraldic device incorporating grey bird?
across.explanation: GOLDCREST(i.e. “bird”). Solution is G (a recognised abbreviation of “grand”, e.g. 100 Gs being 100,000) and CREST (i.e. “heraldic device”) wrapped around or “incorporating” OLD (i.e. “grey”), like so: G-(OLD)-CREST. Chalk one to my Bradford’s.

across.text: Endlessly check one’s first sound system
across.explanation: AUDIO(i.e. “sound system”). Solution is AUDIT (i.e. “check”) with its last letter removed (indicated by “endlessly”) and the remainder followed by O (i.e. “one’s first [letter]”), like so: AUDI-O.

across.text: Tropical tree governor included in unsophisticated paintings?
across.explanation: GREENHEART(i.e. “tropical tree”). Solution is HE (i.e. “governor”, short for His Excellency) placed between or “in” GREEN (i.e. “unsophisticated”) and ART (i.e. “paintings”), like so: GREEN-(HE)-ART. Chalk another to my Bradford’s here. Regular readers will know I have no great love when setters stuff plants into their grids. To be fair, this seems a genuine entry rather than some obscure specimen that barely half a dozen botanists can name, that flowers only once a century in remotest Tibet and, handily, also fits the letters Z_M_Q.

across.text: Travelling salesman, one who hunts with birds of prey
across.explanation: HAWKER. Solution satisfies “travelling salesman” and “one who hunts with birds of prey”.

down.text: One guarantees intemperate speech by men supporting conflict
down.explanation: WARRANTOR(i.e. “one guarantees”). Solution is RANT (i.e. “intemperate speech”) followed by OR (i.e. “men”, specifically the Other Ranks of the British Army). The whole is then placed after or “supporting” – this being a down clue – WAR (i.e. “conflict”), like so: WAR-(RANT-OR).

down.text: Great chap frantically securing ends of uncut thermoplastic
down.explanation: GUTTA-PERCHA(i.e. “thermoplastic”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “frantically”) of GREAT CHAP wrapped around or “securing” UT (i.e. “ends of uncut”, i.e. the first and last letters of “uncut”), like so: G(UT)TAPERCHA. Had to call it something, I guess. One of those “look up gutta in Chambers and see what happens” moments.

down.text: Table including fifty entertainers ultimately of celebrity status
down.explanation: ALL-STAR(i.e. “celebrity status”). Solution is ALTAR (i.e. “table”) wrapped around or “including” L (i.e. “fifty” as a Roman numeral) and S (i.e. “entertainers ultimately”, i.e. the last letter of “entertainers”), like so: AL(L-S)TAR.

down.text: An archdeacon’s type of rosaceous plant
down.explanation: AVENS(i.e. “rosaceous plant”). When written as A VEN’S, the solution also satisfies “an archdeacon’s” – VEN being a recognised abbreviation of “venerable”, an honorific prefix given to archdeacons.

down.text: A law and ceremony identifying a variety of chrysoberyl
down.explanation: ALEXANDRITE(i.e. “a variety of chrysoberyl”. Righto. Glad that’s clear then.) Solution is A followed by LEX (i.e. “law” in Latin), then AND and RITE (i.e. “ceremony”).

down.text: Pitiful, ringing about name in brackets
down.explanation: PARENTHETIC(i.e. “in brackets”). Solution is PATHETIC (i.e. “pitiful”) wrapped around or “ringing” RE (i.e. “about” – think email replies) and N (a recognised abbreviation of “name”) like so: PA(RE-N)THETIC.

down.text: Failure to employ wise man lacking in social graces
down.explanation: NON-USAGE(i.e. “failure to employ”). When written as NON-U SAGE the solution also satisfies “wise man lacking in social graces” – if U is used to describe the upper classes, then NON-U is used to describe the rest of us lowly unwashed.

down.text: I pore over old register, having yen for study of symbolism
down.explanation: ICONOLOGY(i.e. “study of symbolism”). Solution is I followed by CON (i.e. “pore over” – CON is an archaic word for “study” often used by setters in their clues), then O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”), then LOG (i.e. “register”) and Y (a recognised abbreviation of “yen”, the currency of Japan).

down.text: Exercise group supported by a Spanish currency once
down.explanation: PESETA(i.e. “Spanish currency once”). Solution is PE (i.e. “exercise”, specifically Physical Education) followed by SET (i.e. “group”). These are then placed before or “supported by” A – this being a down clue.

down.text: Sadly like a top man’s recurrent urge to steal
down.explanation: KLEPTOMANIA(i.e. “recurrent urge to steal”). “Sadly” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of LIKE A TOP MAN.

down.text: Composition of French art, for example
down.explanation: ESSAY(i.e. “composition”). Solution is ES (i.e. “French art” – setters love using “art” as a ye olde form of “are”, ES is French for “are”, used, I believe, when posing a question, but don’t quote me on that) followed by SAY (i.e. “for example”).

down.text: Area vicars prepared outside an Eastern inn
down.explanation: CARAVANSERAI(i.e. “Eastern inn”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “prepared”) of AREA VICARS wrapped around or placed “outside” of AN, like so: CARAV(AN)SERAI. One I remembered from a previous puzzle, after some mental prodding.

down.text: American character with endless penchant for frogs and things
down.explanation: AMPHIBIA(i.e. “frogs and things”). Solution is AM (a recognised abbreviation of “American”, e.g. how Amex is a contraction of American Express, or how Pan Am is a contraction of Pan American) followed by PHI (i.e. “character”, specifically the twenty-first letter of the Greek alphabet) and BIAS (i.e. “penchant”) once the last letter has been removed (indicated by “endless”), like so: AM-PHI-BIA.

down.text: Greek character given plain description of close family unit
down.explanation: NUCLEAR(i.e. “description of close family unit”). Solution is NU (i.e. “Greek character”, this time the thirteenth letter) followed by CLEAR (i.e. “plain”).

down.text: Kept back comic thought about husband
down.explanation: WITHHELD(i.e. “kept back”). Solution is WIT (i.e. “comic”) followed by HELD (i.e. “thought”) once wrapped “about” H (a recognised abbreviation of “husband”), like so: WIT-H(H)ELD.

down.text: Deliverer turns tail, snatching time for restorative treatment
down.explanation: REST-CURE(i.e. “restorative treatment”). Solution is RESCUER (i.e. “deliverer”) with the last two letters reversed (indicated by “turning tail”) and the whole then wrapped around or “snatching” T (a recognised abbreviation of “time”), like so: RESCU(ER) => RESCU(RE) => RES(T)CURE.

down.text: Greek article framed by an Edinburgh man, perhaps
down.explanation: ATHENIAN(i.e. “Greek character”). Solution is THE (i.e. “article”, as in a word like a, an or the) placed in or “framed by” AN and IAN (i.e. “Edinburgh man, perhaps” – setters love referring to IANs as Scotsmen), like so: A(THE)N-IAN.

down.text: Outfit college introduces for head of maths
down.explanation: UNIFORM(i.e. “outfit”). Solution is UNI (shortened form of university, i.e. “college”) placed before or “introducing” FOR and M (i.e. “head of maths”, i.e. the first letter of “maths”).

down.text: Dreadfully dry hours Noel suffers
down.explanation: HORRENDOUSLY(i.e. “dreadfully”). “Suffers” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of DRY HOURS NOEL.

down.text: Investigator the UN should get replaced
down.explanation: SLEUTHHOUND(i.e. “investigator”). “Get replaced” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of THE UN SHOULD.

down.text: Counting of English mineworkers initially expecting allowance
down.explanation: ENUMERATION(i.e. “counting”). Solution is E (a recognised abbreviation of “English”) followed by NUM (i.e. “mineworkers”, specifically the National Union of Mineworkers), then E (i.e. “initially expecting”, i.e. the first letter of “expecting”) and RATION (i.e. “allowance”).

down.text: Drink with knight in damaged chair, perhaps
down.explanation: CHIPPENDALE(i.e. “chair, perhaps”). Solution is ALE (i.e. “drink”) placed after or “with” N (a recognised abbreviation of “knight” used in chess) once placed “in” CHIPPED (i.e. “damaged”), like so: CHIPPE(N)D-ALE. Toughie, the way it was phrased.

down.text: Repeatedly investigate lookalike, a native of Prague, do we hear?
down.explanation: DOUBLE-CHECK(i.e. “repeatedly investigate”). Solution is DOUBLE (i.e. “lookalike”) followed by a homophone (indicated by “do we hear”) of CZECH (i.e. “a native of Prague”).

down.text: Recruiting group journalists joke about naturally at first
down.explanation: PRESS GANG(i.e. “recruiting group”, not that the “recruits” had much choice in the matter!) Solution is PRESS (i.e. “journalists”) followed by GAG (i.e. “joke”) once wrapped “about” N (i.e. “naturally at first”, i.e. the first letter of “naturally”), like so: PRESS GA(N)G.

down.text: Overcome by amphetamine, heartlessly drive fast car
down.explanation: SPEEDSTER(i.e. “fast car”). Solution is SPEED (slang for “amphetamine”) followed by STEER (i.e. “drive”) once the middle E has been removed (indicated by “heartlessly”), like so: SPEED-STER.

down.text: Slice of veal left over during flight
down.explanation: ESCALOPE(i.e. a boneless “slice of veal” or any meat really). Solution is L (a recognised abbreviation of “left”) and O (ditto “over”, used in cricket) placed “during” ESCAPE (i.e. “flight”), like so: ESCA(L-O)PE.

down.text: Girl with note on central European province
down.explanation: GALICIA(i.e. “central European province” – doesn’t look terribly central European to me, being parked in the north-western corner of Spain, so I might not have this right). Solution is ALICIA (i.e. “girl’s” name) placed after or “with” G (i.e. “[musical] note”), like so: G-ALICIA.[EDIT: Thanks to burleypab in the comments for highlighting a further Galicia which straddles Poland and Ukraine. Cheers! – LP]

down.text: Attention seeking cry heard from solver and doctor?
down.explanation: YOO-HOO(i.e. “attention seeking cry”). Solution is comprised of homophones (indicated by “heard from”) of YOU (i.e. “solver”, from the point of view of the setter) and “Doctor” WHO.

down.text: Conspirator’s son taken in about accountant
down.explanation: Publius ServiliusCASCA(“conspirator” and one of Julius Caesar’s assassins). Solution is S (a recognised abbreviation of “son”) “taken into” C (i.e. “about”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “circa”) and ACA (i.e. “accountant”, specifically an Associate Chartered Accountant), like so: C-A(S)CA.

down.text: Row about introduction of great big cat
down.explanation: TIGER(i.e. “big cat”). Solution is TIER (i.e. “row”) placed “about” G (i.e. “introduction of great”, i.e. the first letter of “great”), like so: TI(G)ER.
